Program name: Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner Cert

Requirements: Unconditional admission to the MSN program may be granted to applicants who meet the following criteria: Hold a Bachelor of Science in Nursing degree from a nationally accredited program (ACEN or CCNE). Have a minimum overall undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale or a 3.0 on the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework. Hold an unencumbered registered nurse license in the state where clinical experiences will be completed. Have completed an undergraduate or graduate statistics course with a grade of C or better. Submit a completed application to the Office of Graduate Admissions. Provide evidence of a minimum of one year of recent clinical experience as a Registered Nurse in an acute care setting. This will be verified by the employing agency. Submission of three recommendation forms (from a current or former supervisor, a peer, and a former faculty member if possible). Submit a resume. Submit a professional goal statement. Applicants may be required to participate in an interview.
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner MSN

Requirements: Unconditional admission to the graduate program at UNA. A Master of Science in Nursing from a regionally accredited institution and a nationally accredited nursing program (ACEN or CCNE). A current, unencumbered registered nurse license in the state where clinical experiences will be completed. A minimum of one year of direct patient care experience as a registered nurse. A minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale on all previous academic work. Successful completion of a 3-credit hour undergraduate or graduate-level statistics course with a grade of C or better. Submission of the following documents to the Office of Graduate Admissions: Official transcripts from all postsecondary institutions attended, Three letters of professional reference attesting to the applicant’s potential for graduate study, A curriculum vitae or resume, A personal statement/essay, Copy of RN license. Submission of a completed background check. Submission of a completed drug screen.
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner Cert

Requirements: Application to the MSN program is a two-part process. Applicants must first apply to the UNA Office of Graduate Admissions. Following application to the University, applicants must complete the Anderson College of Nursing and Health Professions MSN Program Application. Requirements for the Anderson College of Nursing and Health Professions MSN Program application include: a current resume or curriculum vitae; a statement of purpose (500-750 words) describing professional goals and motivation for graduate study; three (3) letters of recommendation; official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended; a current, unencumbered registered nurse license in the state where clinical experiences will occur; a Baccalaureate degree in nursing (BSN) from a regionally accredited institution with ACEN or CCNE program accreditation; an undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or greater on a 4.0 scale; a statistics course with a grade of C or better; and evidence of one year full-time nursing experience as a registered nurse prior to the first clinical course.
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner MSN

Requirements: Admission to the program is based on the student’s undergraduate record and other indicators of aptitude for graduate study. Applicants must have a bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution. Applicants must submit a completed application for admission to graduate study. Applicants must have official transcripts from each institution attended sent directly to the Office of Graduate Admissions. Applicants must have an overall undergraduate grade point average of at least 2.75 on a 4.00 scale. Applicants with an overall undergraduate grade point average of 2.50 to 2.74 on a 4.00 scale will be considered for conditional admission. A formal application to the M.A. in Professional Communication program, statement of purpose, and three letters of recommendation must be submitted to the Department of Communication Graduate Coordinator.

A bachelor's degree from a regionally accredited institution with at least a 3.0 GPA in the last 60 semester hours of undergraduate work. At least 18 hours of previous undergraduate anthropology coursework with a grade of C or better. A formal application to the Graduate School. Official transcripts from each institution attended. A statement of purpose of at least 500 words describing the applicant’s research interests, professional goals, and reasons for pursuing a master’s degree in anthropology at UNA. Three letters of recommendation submitted via the online application system from individuals qualified to judge the applicant's potential for success in a graduate program. At least two letters should be from former professors. A writing sample demonstrating the applicant's ability to conduct research and write a scholarly paper. This should be a research paper written for a previous course. There is no minimum or maximum word count.

Admission into the program will be based on approval from the geology certificate committee. For non-degree seeking students, the University of North Alabama’s requirements for undergraduate and graduate admissions must be met. Current UNA students who wish to earn the certificate should contact Dr. M. Taylor to fill out an application form for program admission. Contact information is on the right side of this page. Students working on the Certificate in Applied Carbonate Geology are expected to maintain a minimum GPA of 3.0 in courses in the certificate program.

Hold a masters or educational specialist degree from an accredited institution. A cumulative GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale on all graduate coursework. Submit an application to the Office of Graduate Admissions. Submit a professional resume or curriculum vitae. Submit official transcripts from all institutions attended. Submit three recommendations from school administrators or supervisors using the Leadership Disposition form. Submit a writing sample that responds to a provided prompt. Instructions on how to complete the writing sample will be sent after the application is submitted. Complete an admissions interview.

Applicants for admission to the Applied Learning Sciences, Ed.D. program should submit the following to the Office of Graduate Admissions: Completed UNA Graduate Application; Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended, including an official transcript that shows a master's degree was conferred from a regionally accredited institution; Three letters of recommendation; A current résumé; A writing sample: An academic paper or professional report which demonstrates the applicant’s potential for success in a doctoral program; A statement of purpose that includes a description of the applicant’s professional goals, research interests, and a rationale for why the applicant is a strong candidate for the Applied Learning Sciences, Ed.D. program; and A minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale on all graduate-level coursework. A screening interview may be required.

Admission to the Applied Physiology Program is based upon the student’s academic background, professional experience, recommendations, and personal statement. In order to be considered for admission, applicants must satisfy the general requirements for admission to graduate study and the Department of Kinesiology.

1. Complete an application to the Graduate Studies Office.
2. Submit three letters of recommendation to the Department of Kinesiology.
3. Provide a written essay that outlines reasons for wanting to obtain a graduate degree in Applied Physiology.
4. Minimum cumulative grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale on all undergraduate coursework.
5. A cumulative grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale on all graduate coursework from a regionally accredited university.
6. Students with a GPA of less than 3.0 must score at the 40th percentile or above on the GRE General Test (verbal and quantitative) to be considered for admission.
7. All students must submit GRE General Test Scores.

A bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited institution with an undergraduate GPA of 2.75 or higher on a 4.0 scale. Official transcripts from all institutions attended. A resume or curriculum vitae. A statement of purpose. Three letters of recommendation. International students whose native language is not English must submit a satisfactory score on the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), International English Language Testing System (IELTS), or Duolingo.

In addition to meeting the university admission requirements for graduate studies, the applicant must:
1. Submit a portfolio of 10-20 images of previous undergraduate or professional work. The portfolio should include samples of hand-drawing, two- and three-dimensional design, and may include architectural drawings, paintings, prints, photographs, and/or sculpture.
2. Submit a 250-word statement of purpose.
3. Submit a resume.
4. Complete a formal interview with program faculty.
Portfolios, resumes, and statements of purpose should be uploaded through the Graduate Admissions application portal.

Submit an application for admission to graduate studies at UNA. Submit official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended to the UNA Office of Graduate Admissions. Have an earned undergraduate degree from a regionally accredited institution with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.5 on a 4.0 scale.

A bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited institution. At least a 2.5 GPA (on a 4.0 scale) in undergraduate degree. Completion of the graduate application. Submission of official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended. A statement of purpose of at least 300 words outlining the applicant’s interest in the field and career goals. A curriculum vitae/resume.

To be admitted to the Arts Presenting Fundamentals Certificate program, applicants must meet one of the following requirements:

1. An earned baccalaureate degree from a regionally accredited institution with a cumulative GPA of 2.50 or higher on a 4.0 scale.
2. An earned graduate degree from a regionally accredited institution with a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher on a 4.0 scale.

Requirements for Clear Admission

1. Completed application for graduate admission.
2. Official baccalaureate degree transcript from a regionally accredited institution.
3. Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended.
4. One of the following:
    * Cumulative undergraduate GPA of 2.50 or higher on a 4.00 scale.
    * Cumulative graduate GPA of 3.00 or higher on a 4.00 scale for a completed graduate degree.

Admission to the Master of Science in Athletic Training (MSAT) program is competitive and based on academic achievement and other selective criteria. The Athletic Training Program Admissions Committee evaluates applicants on the basis of their potential for success in the program and the profession. To be eligible for consideration for admission into the MSAT program, applicants must meet the following criteria:

- Bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited institution
- Minimum cumulative undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale
- Completion of prerequisite coursework with a C or better in all courses
- Completion of 50 observation hours with an athletic trainer
- Three letters of recommendation
- A written essay (500-1000 words) to include:
    - Your career goals and aspirations
    - Your motivation for pursuing the MSAT at UNA
    - The qualities that you possess which you believe will make you a successful student and athletic trainer
- A current resume that includes:
    - Education
    - Work experience
    - Honors/awards
    - Professional organization membership
    - Volunteer/community service
- Completed Athletic Training Program Technical Standards Form

An official transcript from an accredited institution with a baccalaureate degree with a minimum 2.75 GPA. A resume/CV. A statement of purpose (a one page essay detailing your interest in our MPS program). Two letters of recommendation. A writing sample. (A sample of your writing that demonstrates your ability to write clearly and logically. This can be a paper from a previous course, a professional report, or a similar document). Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended.

Admission to the graduate program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology is based on an evaluation by the Biology Graduate Committee of the following application materials:
1. Completed application form with application fee submitted to the Office of Graduate Admissions.
2. Official transcripts of all undergraduate and graduate coursework from accredited institutions.
3. Two letters of recommendation from individuals in professionally relevant fields who can assess the applicant’s potential for success in a graduate program.
4. Statement of purpose that details the applicant’s interest in the MS in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology program at UNA and includes long-term goals.
5. Resume or curriculum vitae.
6. Students for whom English is a second language must meet the University requirements for English proficiency (see University Requirements for Graduate Study).

Completed online application and $50 application fee.
Official transcripts from all institutions attended. A master’s degree in a STEM field from a regionally accredited institution is required for admission with a minimum graduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
An official GRE score report is required for consideration of admission. The GRE may be waived for applicants who have at least five years of significant, professional work experience.
Resume or curriculum vitae (CV).
Statement of Purpose that describes in 500-1000 words the applicant’s interest in the program and reason for pursuing the Executive Ph.D. degree.
Three letters of recommendation submitted through the online application portal from professional or academic references who can attest to the applicant's potential for success in a doctoral program.
Program name: Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Executive PhD Online

Requirements: A bachelor's degree in biomedical engineering or a related engineering field, from a regionally accredited institution, or a bachelor's degree in a STEM field such as physics, chemistry, biology, or mathematics, with a minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. Prerequisite coursework: Differential Equations and Linear Algebra. Application to the UNA Graduate Studies. Official transcripts from all institutions attended. Three letters of recommendation from individuals who can speak to the applicant's academic potential. A Statement of Purpose describing the applicant's research interests and career goals. A current resume or curriculum vitae (CV).
Program name: Biomedical Engineering MSBE with emphasis in Medical Physics
Biomedical Engineering PhD with emphasis in Medical Physics

Requirements:
The requirements for unconditional admission to the Master of Science degree in Biomedical and Health Sciences are:
- A bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited institution, or the international equivalent, with a minimum cumulative undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
- A personal statement of 500 words or less.
- Two letters of recommendation from individuals in a supervisory or professional capacity who can attest to the applicant's potential for success in a graduate program.
- Submission of all official transcripts from each post-secondary institution attended.

The following materials should be submitted as part of the application for admission to the PIBS program at UNA: A completed application for admission to graduate study; Official transcripts of all undergraduate and graduate credits from each institution attended; An official report of the General Test of the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) scores from the Educational Testing Service. Scores older than five years will not be accepted; Three letters of recommendation; A personal statement; A resume or curriculum vitae; A completed Department of Biology Graduate Program Application.

To be admitted to the MS in Mathematics Program, a student must satisfy the general admission requirements for the Office of Graduate Studies, and be admitted to graduate study at UNA. In addition, the Department of Mathematics requires the applicant to meet the following criteria: 1. An undergraduate major in Mathematics or a related field with at least a 3.0 GPA on a 4.0 scale. 2. Must have completed Calculus I, II, III and at least one additional upper division proof-based course. 3. Students must submit an essay stating their reasons for pursuing a graduate degree in mathematics and their professional goals. 4. Students must submit three letters of recommendation with at least two from university faculty in Mathematics or a closely related discipline.

Completed application for admission to graduate study. An official transcript from the college or university that awarded the student's master's degree. Official transcripts from all other colleges and universities attended. A minimum GPA of 3.25 on a 4.0 scale on all previous graduate course work. A master's degree in a field relevant to exercise science and health promotion (e.g., Kinesiology, Exercise Science, Nutrition, Biomechanics, Public Health, Health Promotion, etc.) from a regionally accredited institution. A current resume or curriculum vitae. A statement of purpose (approximately 500-1000 words) that describes the applicant’s research interests and career goals and explains how the PhD in Exercise Science and Health Promotion will help the applicant achieve these goals. The statement of purpose should also identify at least one faculty member in the department with whom the applicant would like to work. Three letters of recommendation from individuals who can attest to the applicant's academic potential and suitability for doctoral study. A personal interview (in person or via video conference) may be required.

Admission to the Master of Professional Studies program requires: 1. a bachelor's degree from a regionally accredited institution. 2. an undergraduate GPA of 2.75 or higher on a 4.0 scale. 3. completion of the UNA Graduate Application. 4. official transcripts from all institutions attended. 5. a written statement of purpose describing the applicant's professional goals and reasons for pursuing the MPS degree. 6. three letters of recommendation. 7. an up-to-date résumé.

The Certificate in Business program is open to non-business majors who want to broaden their knowledge in the fundamentals of business. The required curriculum includes six courses (18 hours) listed below. To enroll in these courses, a student must meet the prerequisite for each course, as listed in the catalog.

Applicants for the Executive Doctor of Business Administration must have:

An MBA, or equivalent business-focused Master's degree, from an AACSB-accredited or EQUIS-accredited institution.
At least 10 years of professional/managerial experience.
Significant managerial experience with demonstrated career progression.

The application requires the following:

A formal application with application fee
Official transcripts from all universities attended
A current resume
A statement of purpose
Three professional recommendations
A formal interview with EDBA Admissions Committee

A master's degree in a business-related discipline from an accredited institution. A minimum of seven years of professional and/or teaching experience, with a minimum of three years of mid- to upper-level management experience preferred. A grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 or higher (on a 4.0 scale) on all previous graduate coursework. Applicants must submit a current professional resume, a statement of purpose, and an official transcript from all previously attended colleges and universities. Three professional letters of reference are required for a complete application. The GMAT or GRE is not required for admission. The admissions committee will conduct an interview with all qualified applicants.

To be considered for admission to the Executive Doctorate in Business Administration (EDBA) program, applicants must submit the following:

*   Completed Application
*   Master's Degree (any discipline) from a regionally accredited university.
*   Official Transcripts from ALL universities attended (graduate and undergraduate)
*   Current Résumé
*   Statement of Purpose
*   Two Letters of Recommendation
*   A minimum of eight years of progressive management and/or leadership experience. Senior-level management and/or leadership experience is preferred.
*   A personal interview with the EDBA Admissions Committee will be required for applicants that are identified as potential candidates.
*   International students must meet UNA's international admission requirements.

Admission to the Executive Doctor of Business Administration (EDBA) program is limited and competitive. Successful applicants must meet the following minimum requirements:

- A master’s degree in business or a related field from a regionally accredited institution, or its equivalent, from a foreign institution.
- A minimum of five years of significant managerial or leadership experience that demonstrates increasing levels of responsibility.
- A complete application submitted to the Office of Graduate Admissions, including:
    - Completed online application for admission and a non-refundable application fee.
    - Official transcripts from all universities attended.
    - A current resume.
    - Three professional letters of recommendation that address the applicant’s professional accomplishments and potential for success in a rigorous doctoral program.
    - A statement of purpose (approximately 1,500 words) that describes the applicant’s motivation for pursuing the EDBA, long-term professional goals, and a potential research topic.
    - An interview with the Director of the EDBA program.
- International applicants are required to submit a TOEFL, IELTS, or PTE score if the master’s degree was not from a US university.

A master’s degree in business or a related field from a regionally accredited institution.
A minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale on all previous graduate coursework.
A minimum of three years of mid-to-senior level professional/managerial experience. Exceptions may be granted for applicants with exceptional academic backgrounds.
An online application and a $100 non-refundable application fee.
Official transcripts from all universities attended (undergraduate and graduate).
Three letters of recommendation.
A current resume or curriculum vitae (CV).
A personal statement of 500-750 words outlining the applicant’s personal and professional goals and how the EDBA program will help achieve those goals.
An interview (online or in person).

Undergraduate students at the University of North Alabama who have completed at least 75 undergraduate credit hours with a minimum overall GPA of 3.0 may apply for admission to the Accelerated Master’s Program (AMP). Admission to the AMP allows students to take up to 12 graduate credit hours that may be used to satisfy requirements for both the bachelor’s and master’s degrees. Admission to the AMP is not the same as admission to the graduate program. AMP students will apply to the graduate program after completion of their undergraduate degree. If all other graduate admission requirements are met, then the student is fully admitted to the graduate program.

The UNA MBA is open to all students with a four-year baccalaureate degree from a regionally accredited college or university. No GMAT or GRE is required for admission. Admission can be granted in one of two ways:

Unconditional Admission
An earned bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited institution with a minimum 2.5 cumulative GPA.
Official transcripts from all universities/colleges attended.
Two letters of recommendation.
A current résumé.
A 250 word Statement of Purpose.

Alternative Admission
An earned bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited institution with a minimum 2.0-2.49 cumulative GPA.
Three years of approved and documented professional work experience.
Official transcripts from all universities/colleges attended.
Two letters of recommendation.
A current résumé.
A 250 word Statement of Purpose.
Program name: Business Administration Accelerated MBA in Real Estate

Requirements: Completed application for graduate studies at UNA with non-refundable application fee. Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended sent directly to the Office of Graduate Admissions at UNA. A bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution with a minimum 2.75 GPA on a 4.0 scale. A current resume detailing at least 5 years of significant managerial or leadership experience. A one-page statement of purpose that clearly explains the applicant’s interest in the EMBA program and future career aspirations. Two letters of recommendation.
Program name: Business Administration Executive MBA in Health Management and Policy

Requirements: A bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution. Official transcripts from all universities attended. A current professional resume that reflects at least five years of progressive work experience. A completed application for graduate admission at UNA. Two letters of recommendation. An admission essay. A personal interview with the Director of the Executive MBA Program.

An undergraduate degree from an accredited institution.
A cumulative undergraduate GPA of 2.50 or higher.
Official transcripts from all universities attended.
International students must satisfy additional requirements, including TOEFL, and provide a transcript evaluation.
GMAT/GRE is NOT required.

Applicants for admission to the M.S. in Business Technology must meet the following criteria:
- Completed Application for Graduate Admission
- Official transcripts from all universities and colleges attended sent directly to the Office of Graduate Admissions
- A current résumé
- If an applicant meets one of the following criteria, the GMAT/GRE requirement is waived:
  - An undergraduate degree from a regionally-accredited university or college with a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher.
  - An undergraduate degree from a regionally-accredited university or college with a cumulative GPA of 2.75 or higher AND three years of relevant, professional work experience.
  - An awarded graduate degree from a regionally-accredited university.
- Applicants who do not meet one of the criteria above must submit official scores for the Graduate Management Admission Test (GMAT) or Graduate Record Examination (GRE) that are less than five years old.
- To be considered for unconditional admission, an applicant must have a score of 450 or higher on the GMAT, or a score of 290 or higher on the GRE, and meet one of the following criteria:
  - An undergraduate degree from a regionally-accredited university or college with a cumulative GPA of 2.75 or higher.
  - An undergraduate degree from a regionally-accredited university or college with a cumulative GPA of 2.5 or higher and three years of professional work experience.

Program name: Cellular Physiology and Molecular Biophysics PhD

Requirements: Complete the application for admission to the Graduate School. Submit a current resume. Submit a letter of application to the program addressing personal and professional qualifications and aspirations relevant to the counseling profession. Submit official transcripts from all institutions attended. A minimum undergraduate GPA of 2.75 on a 4.0 scale is required for Unconditional Admission. Submit names and email addresses for three professional/academic references who can address the applicant's potential for success in the counseling profession. References will be prompted to complete a recommendation form. Submit a score from the Miller Analogies Test (MAT) or the Graduate Record Exam (GRE-Verbal and Quantitative). Applicants meeting all of the above admission requirements will be invited for a personal interview with faculty in the Counselor Education program.

An official transcript from the college or university that awarded the baccalaureate degree and official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. Submit a score from one of the following tests: GRE (verbal and quantitative sections), MAT, or GMAT. The test score must be no older than five years from the date of the examination. The GMAT, GRE and MAT requirement is temporarily waived through Fall 2024 for students with a 3.0 or higher cumulative GPA on their conferred bachelor's degree. Submit a Statement of Purpose. Submit three letters of recommendation. Submit a resume/vitae. Submit a writing sample. Have a minimum undergraduate GPA of 2.50 for unconditional admission.
Program name: Data Analytics and Program Evaluation MS Online

Requirements:
Application for admission to the Graduate School.
Bachelor of Science in Nursing degree from a regionally accredited institution and a nationally accredited nursing program (ACEN or CCNE).
Current unencumbered registered nurse license in the United States.
Minimum undergraduate grade point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended.
A current resume or curriculum vitae.
Goal Statement. The goal statement should be a maximum of 500 words describing your reasons for pursuing the DNP, your short and long-term professional goals, and how you see yourself as a DNP-prepared nurse.
Three letters of recommendation. Recommendations should be from individuals who can attest to your potential for success in a graduate program (examples include: current or former professors, current or former supervisors, and other professional colleagues).
Completion of an undergraduate or graduate statistics course with a grade of C or better.
Completion of an undergraduate or graduate research course with a grade of C or better.
Completion of an undergraduate or graduate physical assessment course with a grade of C or better.
Successful interview with DNP faculty.
Program name: Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP): Advanced Practice

Requirements:
Application to the Office of Graduate Admissions at UNA. The application can be found at www.una.edu/graduate.
Minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale on all graduate coursework.
Current unencumbered RN license in the state where clinical experiences will occur.
Current certification as a nurse practitioner or clinical nurse specialist from a national certifying body.
Master of Science in Nursing (MSN) or a Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) from a nationally accredited nursing program (Accreditation Commission for Education in Nursing [ACEN] or Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education [CCNE]).
Submission of the following documents to the Office of Graduate Admissions:
Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended.
Verification of clinical hours from previous graduate nursing program (must meet the 1000-hour requirement post-BSN).
Current resume or curriculum vitae (CV).
Professional portfolio to include:
A written statement describing professional goals and how the DNP degree will help to achieve those goals.
A scholarly paper from a previous graduate program.
Evidence of scholarship (e.g., publications, presentations, grant funding, etc.).
Evidence of professional service.
Three letters of professional reference attesting to the applicant’s potential for doctoral study.
Interview with graduate nursing faculty.
Program name: Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP): Population Health
Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP): Educational Leadership

Requirements:
Each applicant to an Education Specialist degree program must apply and be admitted to Graduate Studies at the University of North Alabama. Applicants to the Education Specialist degree program in Teacher Education must also:

1. Hold a master’s degree from a regionally accredited institution.
2. Have a minimum graduate grade point average of 3.25 on a 4.0 scale.
3. Hold a valid Alabama Class A professional educator certificate in the desired area of concentration (or the equivalent from another state).
4. Have a minimum of two full years of full-time, acceptable P-12 professional educational work experience.
5. Submit two letters of recommendation. At least one must be from a current supervisor who can attest to the applicant’s professional leadership abilities. The second can be from another school administrator or a university faculty member.
6. Submit a Statement of Intent. The Statement of Intent should be a two-page, double-spaced essay that describes the applicant’s reasons for pursuing an Education Specialist degree and how the degree will help the applicant in his/her professional growth. In addition, applicants should describe their long-term career goals and professional aspirations.
7. Complete a successful interview with the program admission committee.

Hold a master’s degree from a regionally accredited institution.
Have a minimum graduate GPA of 3.25 on a 4.0 scale.
Have a valid Alabama Class A professional educator certificate in a teaching field or instructional support area.
Have a minimum of three full years of full-time, acceptable professional educational work experience in a P-12 setting.
Complete an interview.
Submit a portfolio that includes a resume, leadership statement, three letters of recommendation, service/leadership documentation, and a valid Alabama Class A certificate.
Submit a writing sample.

To be eligible for unconditional admission to the Education Specialist program, applicants must hold a master's degree from a regionally accredited institution and a valid Class A Professional Educator Certificate in a teaching field or area of instructional support. Applicants who hold a valid Class A Professional Educator Certificate in a teaching field or area of instructional support must have an admission portfolio that includes: official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended with a minimum GPA of 3.25 on a 4.0 scale on all graduate coursework, a copy of valid Class A Professional Educator Certificate, verification of three full years of full-time, satisfactory P-12 professional educational work experience, a letter of intent, a professional resume, three letters of recommendation, an acceptable score on a writing assessment, and a successful interview.

To be considered for admission to the Master of Science in Electrical and Computer Engineering (MSECE) program, applicants must hold a bachelor's degree in Electrical Engineering, Computer Engineering, or a closely related field from a regionally accredited institution. Applicants with a bachelor's degree in other disciplines of engineering, computer science, mathematics, or physics may be considered for admission but may be required to complete some undergraduate prerequisite courses. A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale is required. No GRE is required for admission. International students must satisfy English language proficiency requirements as stated in the Graduate Catalog.
Program name: Electrical and Computer Engineering MSECE with emphasis in Artificial Intelligence

Requirements:
Admission to the MSECE program is based on a holistic review of each applicant’s file. The MSECE program welcomes applicants with a bachelor’s degree from an ABET-accredited Electrical Engineering, Computer Engineering, or a closely related program with an overall GPA of 3.0 or higher. Applicants not meeting these criteria will be considered on an individual basis and may be subject to additional undergraduate coursework as prescribed by the graduate program coordinator.

Application Requirements:
1. Completed application to the UNA Office of Graduate Admissions.
2. Official transcripts from all postsecondary institutions attended submitted directly to the UNA Office of Graduate Admissions.
3. Statement of Purpose that explains why you would like to pursue the MSECE program at UNA and what makes you an ideal candidate.
4. Resume that shows your educational and professional background.
5. Two letters of recommendation from faculty and/or supervisors.
Program name: Electrical and Computer Engineering MSECE with emphasis in Cybersecurity

Requirements: An application to the Graduate Studies Office; Official transcripts from all universities and colleges attended sent directly to the Graduate Studies Office; An official score report on the General Test of the Graduate Record Examination (GRE), taken within the last five years; A 10-15 page writing sample in English or American literature; Three letters of recommendation; A statement of purpose

Applicants must meet the general admission requirements of the Office of Graduate Studies. Additional requirements for admission to the Industrial Hygiene master’s program are as follows:
1. A baccalaureate degree from a regionally accredited institution, preferably with a major or minor in industrial hygiene, chemistry, biology, or engineering. Students with degrees in other areas are encouraged to apply, but may be required to complete undergraduate prerequisite courses.
2. An official transcript from the institution granting the baccalaureate degree.
3. A minimum grade point average of 2.75 (on a 4.0 scale) on all undergraduate work.
4. Submission of an official score on the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) general test. GRE Requirement has been waived until further notice.
5. Two letters of recommendation from former professors or supervisors who can attest to the applicant's academic potential.
6. Proficiency in English is a requirement for admission.

Completed Application for Graduate Admission to UNA with a non-refundable application fee.
Official transcripts from all institutions attended.
Master’s Degree in Exercise Science or a related field (e.g., Kinesiology, Health and Human Performance, Public Health, Nutrition).
Minimum graduate GPA of 3.25 on a 4.0 scale.
Official scores on the Graduate Record Examination (GRE). A minimum combined verbal and quantitative score of 297 is required. The analytical writing component is NOT REQUIRED.
A letter of intent/purpose describing the applicant’s interest in the program and desired emphasis area.
A curriculum vitae/resume.
Three letters of recommendation addressing the applicant’s potential for success in a doctoral program. Applicants will provide contact information for references in the graduate application portal, and the portal will send a recommendation request directly to the references.
International students must satisfy additional requirements for admission to the university, which can be found at https://www.una.edu/international/admissions-requirements.html.
An interview (virtual or in-person) with the program admissions committee may be requested.

To be considered for admission to the Master of Professional Studies program, a student must:
1. Hold a bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution.
2. Have an overall grade point average of at least 2.50 on a 4.00 scale in all undergraduate work attempted. Applicants with an undergraduate GPA below 2.50 may be admitted on a conditional basis.
3. Submit a completed application to the Office of Graduate Admissions.

All applicants for admission to the master's degree program in Health and Human Performance must: 1. Meet all Graduate Studies admission requirements. 2. Submit the following directly to the Office of Graduate Admissions: a. Completed Graduate Application for Admission b. Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended with a degree posted from a regionally accredited institution c. Official scores on the General Test of the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) or the Miller Analogies Test (MAT). d. Three letters of recommendation. e. Written narrative. The narrative must not exceed two double-spaced pages, and it must address the applicant's professional goals and purpose for pursuing a graduate degree in health and human performance. 3. Possess an undergraduate overall grade point average of 2.75 or 3.0 on the last 30 semester hours.
Program name: Health and Human Performance (Master's level, non-certification)

Requirements:
Unconditional admission to the graduate program in history requires:
1. A bachelor's degree from a regionally accredited institution,
2. An undergraduate major in history with a 3.0 grade point average or better on a 4.0 scale or a minimum of 27 semester hours in history and related fields with a 3.0 grade point average or better,
3. A writing sample (a research paper from an upper-division undergraduate history course is preferred), and
4. Three letters of recommendation.

In some cases, a student who does not meet the above criteria may be granted conditional admission. See below for details on how to fulfill conditional admission requirements.

To be considered for admission to the Master of Science in Instructional Design and Technology, students must meet the following criteria:

A baccalaureate degree in any discipline from an accredited institution.
A minimum undergraduate GPA of 2.75 on a 4.00 scale.
Two letters of recommendation.
A Statement of Purpose outlining the applicant’s interest in the program and career goals. Applicants may follow this template to craft their Statement of Purpose.
A current resume.
International students must satisfy additional requirements, including evidence of English language proficiency.
Program name: Instructional Design and Technology MS Online: Teaching, Learning, and Leading

Requirements: Admission to the Instructional Design and Technology program requires applicants to have an undergraduate degree from a regionally accredited university and a cumulative GPA of 2.75 or higher. Applicants not meeting the 2.75 GPA requirement may be admitted conditionally to the program.
Program name: Instructional Design and Technology MS Online: Learning and Development

Requirements:
To be eligible for unconditional admission to the MAEd/MSEd program in School Counseling, the applicant must:
1. Meet all Graduate School admission requirements.
2. Possess a valid bachelor's-level professional educator certificate in a teaching field, OR meet requirements for a Class B Alabama professional educator certificate in a teaching field.
3. Two years of full-time, satisfactory P-12 professional educational work experience.
4. Submit three recommendations from individuals who can speak to the applicant’s potential for success in the school counseling program. At least one recommendation must come from a current or former P-12 administrator.
5. Submit a satisfactory score on the Alabama Educator Certification Assessment Program (AECAP) basic skills assessments.
6. Submit a writing sample that responds to a prompt provided by the program.
7. Complete a successful interview with program faculty.
8. Submit a clear background check.
Program name: Master of Arts in Education (MAEd): School Counseling

Requirements:
In addition to meeting the general admission requirements for graduate studies, the applicant must:

1. hold a valid bachelor’s level professional educator certificate in elementary education (K-6).
2. submit a copy of his/her valid teaching certificate.
3. submit three letters of recommendation with at least one from a current or former administrator.
4. submit a written essay describing why the applicant wants to pursue this master’s degree and his/her career goals.
5. submit a portfolio containing at least two artifacts from the applicant’s teaching career. At least one artifact must showcase the applicant’s skills in technology integration in the classroom. Each artifact must be accompanied by a brief explanation of the artifact.
6. submit a resume describing past work and educational experiences.
7. participate in a personal interview.
Program name: Master of Arts in Education (MAEd): Elementary Education K-6

Requirements: To be eligible for unconditional admission to the MAEd program, a student must have a bachelor's degree from a regionally accredited institution and meet the requirements for admission to the College of Graduate Studies. Additional admission requirements are as follows: Hold a valid Alabama Class B Professional Educator Certificate in the chosen teaching field OR meet the requirements for an Alabama Class B Professional Educator Certificate in the chosen teaching field. Submit a score on the general test of the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) that meets the minimum score requirement set by the Alabama State Department of Education (ALSDE). (Currently, a score of 290 combined on the verbal and quantitative sections is required for admission to a Class A program). NOTE: The GRE requirement is waived for applicants who have earned a master’s degree from a regionally accredited institution. Submit three letters of recommendation. Submit a writing sample that addresses the student’s reasons for pursuing the degree. Submit a copy of a valid teaching certificate. Submit official transcripts from all institutions attended. Submit a completed application to the College of Graduate Studies.
Program name: Master of Arts in Education (MAEd): Secondary Education

Requirements: Meet all university graduate admission requirements. Hold a bachelor's level professional educator certificate in the same teaching field(s) in which the Class A professional educator certificate is sought... Have a minimum GPA of 3.00 on all undergraduate coursework OR 3.25 on all graduate coursework... Provide a copy of their valid teaching certificate. Provide a Service Record form verifying a minimum of one full year of full-time satisfactory P-12 teaching experience... Applicants who do not meet requirement #5 may be admitted but must complete a 300-clock-hour internship... Provide three letters of recommendation... Provide a writing sample to be evaluated by program faculty... Provide a resume... A successful interview with program faculty may be required.
Program name: Master of Arts in Education (MAEd): P-12 Education (selected teaching fields)

Requirements: An official transcript from the institution that awarded the baccalaureate degree. A valid teaching certificate. Three years of P-12 professional educational work experience. Two letters of recommendation, including one from the applicant's current principal or supervisor. A completed Instructional Leadership Supplemental Application. A qualifying score on either the Miller Analogies Test (MAT) or the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) (Verbal plus Quantitative). A completed 'Verification of Educational Experience' form. A completed 'Principal Recommendation' form. An essay (see department for prompt). A successful interview with the Instructional Leadership Admissions Committee.
Program name: Master of Arts in Education (MAEd): Instructional Leadership

Requirements: To be considered for admission to the MAEd Special Education: Collaborative Teacher K-6 or 6-12 program, applicants must meet the following requirements: A completed application for admission to Graduate Studies. Official transcripts from all institutions attended. An overall undergraduate GPA of at least 2.75, or a GPA of at least 3.00 on the last 30 semester hours of undergraduate work. A valid bachelor’s level professional educator certificate in any teaching field (from Alabama or another state). Two years of full-time, satisfactory P-12 teaching experience. A writing sample that demonstrates the applicant’s writing ability. The writing sample will be evaluated based on the following: content/organization, grammar/mechanics, and style/format. A successful interview with the program faculty. Submission of the 'Verification of Educational Experience' form.
Program name: Master of Arts in Education (MAEd): Special Education: Collaborative Teacher K-6 and/or 6-12

Requirements: Applicants must meet the general requirements for graduate admission which include completing the application for admission, paying the nonrefundable application fee, and submitting official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. The University of North Alabama has temporarily waived the graduate entrance exam requirement (GRE/GMAT/MAT) for all graduate programs through Fall 2025. For the Class A certification track, an applicant must hold a bachelor’s level professional educator certificate in the same teaching field. For the non-certification track, an applicant must hold a bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited institution.
Program name: Master of Arts in Education (MAEd) in Secondary Education-English/Language Arts

Requirements:
Submit a completed Application for Admission to the Office of Graduate Admissions.
Submit official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended to the Office of Graduate Admissions.
Possess an undergraduate degree with a minimum grade point average (GPA) of 2.75 from a regionally accredited institution, or a GPA of 3.0 on the last 30 semester hours.
Submission of an official score report of one of the following:
Praxis II subject area assessment with a passing score
Miller Analogies Test (MAT) with a score of 388 or higher
Graduate Record Examination (GRE) with a score of 294 (Verbal + Quantitative) or higher.
A 24-30 semester hour major in the teaching field with a GPA of 2.75 or above. (Must be approved by the Department of Secondary Education.) All courses in the major must be completed with a grade of C or better. Courses must meet Alabama State Board of Education course distribution requirements.
Submission of an acceptable writing sample as specified by the department.
Three letters of recommendation.
Submission of a resume.
Submission of a narrative describing the applicant’s commitment to the profession of teaching, expectations of the program, and any personal experiences relevant to teaching.
Submission of a completed Disposition Form.
Submission of a verified background clearance.
Program name: Master of Arts in Education (MAEd) in Secondary Education – English/Language Arts – Alternative Plan

Requirements:
Unconditional Admission to the Master of Science in Exercise Science and Health Promotion program requires the following:
1. An earned bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited institution with a minimum 2.75 grade point average (4.0 scale) in the last 60 hours of undergraduate coursework, or a minimum 2.5 grade point average overall.
2. Official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended must be provided.
3. Successful completion of the following undergraduate courses with a C or better:
    * Human Anatomy and Physiology I with lab
    * Human Anatomy and Physiology II with lab
    * Exercise Physiology with lab
    * Kinesiology/Biomechanics
4. Submission of a 500-word essay detailing professional goals and reasons for pursuing a graduate degree at UNA.
5. Submission of a resume of professional and educational experiences.
Program name: Master of Science in Exercise Science and Health Promotion: Exercise Science

Requirements: Admission to the Office of Graduate Studies. For unconditional admission, a minimum overall undergraduate GPA of 2.75 on a 4.0 scale. For conditional admission, an overall undergraduate GPA of 2.50 to 2.74 on a 4.0 scale. No additional application materials are required.
Program name: Master of Science in Exercise Science and Health Promotion: Kinesiology

Requirements:
To be considered for admission to the Master of Science in Exercise Science & Health Promotion, applicants must meet the general requirements for admission to the Office of Graduate Studies. Applicants must also submit the following directly to the Office of Graduate Studies:

*   Completed application for graduate studies
*   Official transcripts from all institutions attended
*   Three letters of recommendation
*   A two-page essay explaining your background in exercise science, personal philosophy of wellness and professional career goals
*   Official GRE scores (verbal and quantitative) taken within the last five years are required if undergraduate GPA is below 3.0
*   Additional documents may be requested
Program name: Master of Science in Exercise Science and Health Promotion: Wellness and Health Promotion

Requirements: Admission to the M.S. in mathematics program requires an undergraduate degree from an accredited institution with an undergraduate major in mathematics or a major with a substantial number of mathematics courses. An applicant with a bachelor's degree in a field other than mathematics may also be admitted upon completion, with satisfactory grades, of the mathematics courses prerequisite for the master’s program. Admission to the program also requires a minimum overall undergraduate GPA of 2.50. An applicant with a GPA between 2.0 and 2.49 may be admitted conditionally. Application is made to the Office of Graduate Admissions.
Program name: Master of Science in Mathematics (MS) Degree

Requirements: Application to the Office of Graduate Admissions. Official transcripts from each institution attended. A Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) degree from a regionally accredited institution and a nursing program accredited by the Accreditation Commission for Education in Nursing (ACEN), or the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (CCNE). An overall undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. Current unencumbered licensure as a registered nurse (RN) in the United States. A minimum of one-year full-time nursing experience as a registered nurse prior to clinical courses. Three letters of recommendation from persons who can attest to the applicant’s academic and/or professional abilities. A curriculum vitae or resume. A Statement of Purpose that addresses how the MSN degree will help the applicant meet professional and personal goals.
Program name: Master of Science in Nursing (MSN): Nursing in Teaching-Learning Environment

Requirements: Complete application to Graduate Admissions. Official transcripts from all institutions of higher learning with an overall GPA of 3.0 or greater on a 4.0 scale. Hold an unencumbered license as a registered nurse in the United States. Two professional recommendations addressing professional competence. One recommendation from the immediate supervisor is preferred. Successful completion of an undergraduate statistics course with a grade of C or better. Successful completion of an undergraduate nursing research course with a grade of C or better. Personal statement/essay of 500 words or less addressing a time the applicant influenced change in practice. Resume detailing nursing experience.
Program name: Master of Science in Nursing (MSN): Nursing Leadership in Organizational Environments

Requirements:
1. Meet all admission requirements of the Office of Graduate Studies.
2. BSN from a nationally accredited nursing program (ACEN or CCNE).
3. A minimum overall undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale or a GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale on the last 60 semester hours of undergraduate work. A holistic review will be considered on an individual basis for all applicants meeting minimum Graduate Studies admission requirements.
4. Current unencumbered RN licensure in the state where clinicals will be completed.
5. Evidence of completion of an undergraduate or graduate statistics course with a grade of C or better.
6. Submission of three letters of professional reference attesting to the applicant's potential for graduate study. It is recommended that at least one reference be from a faculty who can attest to academic ability and one from a supervisor who can attest to clinical practice. Professional references from colleagues are acceptable. References from relatives are not acceptable.
7. Submission of a curriculum vitae/resume'.
8. A personal statement describing professional goals.
9. A personal interview may be required.
Program name: Master of Science in Nursing (MSN): Family Nurse Practitioner

Requirements: Admission to the Master of Science in Sport and Recreation Management requires: 1. a completed application for admission to graduate study; 2. an official transcript from the college or university that awarded the baccalaureate degree; 3. official transcripts from all other colleges and universities attended; 4. a score on the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) general test (verbal and quantitative) or the Miller Analogies Test (MAT) that meets one of the following criteria: a. An undergraduate GPA of 2.75 or above on a 4.00 scale and a GRE score of at least 286 (verbal + quantitative) or a MAT score of at least 370. b. An undergraduate GPA of 3.00 or above on a 4.00 scale and a GRE score of at least 283 (verbal + quantitative) or a MAT score of at least 360. c. An undergraduate GPA between 2.50 and 2.74 and a GRE score of 290 or a MAT score of 380. d. A completed graduate degree from a regionally accredited institution with at least a 3.00 GPA. 5. three letters of recommendation; and 6. approval from the department. (Meeting the minimum requirements does not guarantee admission.)
Program name: Master of Science (MS) Degree in Sport and Recreation Management: Sport Management

Requirements:
To be considered for unconditional admission to the Sport and Recreation Management program, the applicant must have an undergraduate degree from an accredited institution and meet the requirement for admission to the College of Graduate Studies. The undergraduate degree can be in any discipline. Applicants must have a minimum undergraduate grade point average (GPA) of 2.75 overall OR 3.0 on the last 30 semester hours.

Applicants who do not meet the unconditional GPA requirement may be eligible for conditional admission with an undergraduate GPA between 2.50 and 2.74 and submission of a 500-word statement of purpose. Students admitted conditionally must maintain a minimum 3.0 GPA in the first nine (9) hours of graduate coursework at UNA to remain in the program.
Program name: Master of Science (MS) Degree in Sport and Recreation Management: Recreation Management

Requirements: Admission to the Master of Arts in Philosophy program requires the applicant to hold a baccalaureate degree from an accredited institution. Admission also requires submission of the following: Completed application to the Office of Graduate Admissions, A 300-400 word statement of purpose outlining the applicant's interest in the program, A 7-10 page writing sample that displays the applicant's philosophical writing abilities, Two letters of recommendation from former professors that testify to the applicant's academic abilities, Official transcripts from all institutions attended.

Applicants must hold a baccalaureate degree from a regionally accredited institution, completed prior to the start of the DPT program. A minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale is required for both cumulative GPA and prerequisite course GPA. All prerequisite coursework must be completed with a C or better prior to the start of the DPT program, and science prerequisites must have been completed within 10 years of application. Official transcripts from all institutions attended must be sent to PTCAS. Three letters of recommendation are required and must be submitted through PTCAS; one must be from a licensed physical therapist. A minimum of 40 observation hours under the supervision of a licensed physical therapist are required from at least two different settings. The PTCAS application includes an essay that will be reviewed. GRE Scores are NOT required for admission. Qualified applicants will be invited for a required virtual interview.

Prospective students must meet the following minimum requirements:
1. Complete the University of North Alabama Graduate Application.
2. Submit official transcripts from all institutions attended to the Office of Graduate Admissions.
3. Hold a Master's degree in a related field from an accredited institution.
4. An overall minimum grade point average of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale for all graduate coursework.
5. Submission of a written statement of purpose.
6. Three letters of recommendation.
7. A curriculum vita (CV)/resume.
8. A writing sample from their Master’s degree work.
9. An interview with the Doctoral Admissions Committee.
10. For international students, please see requirements for International Graduate Students.

A minimum grade point average (GPA) of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale is required for admission. Admission to the M.S. in Physics program requires the GRE General Test. A waiver of the GRE may be requested with a cumulative GPA of 3.5 or higher from a regionally accredited U.S. institution. An undergraduate degree in physics or a related field is required for admission. Students with a baccalaureate degree in a field other than physics may be admitted to the program; however, they may be required to successfully complete select undergraduate coursework in physics and/or mathematics prior to being admitted. Three letters of recommendation are required from individuals who are qualified to assess the applicant’s potential for success in a graduate physics program. These letters should be submitted directly by the references to the Office of Graduate Admissions. A Statement of Purpose must be submitted to the Office of Graduate Admissions that addresses the applicant’s motivation for pursuing graduate studies, their research interests, and their career goals. A Resume or Curriculum Vitae must be submitted to the Office of Graduate Admissions that summarizes the applicant’s educational background, work experience, research experience, publications, presentations, and any other relevant accomplishments.

In addition to meeting the minimum requirements for admission to graduate study at UNA, applicants to the M.S. in Prevention Science and Community Health must submit the following materials:

1. Letter of Intent describing the applicant’s interest in the program and career goals
2. Current Résumé or Vita
3. Three letters of recommendation
4. Official transcripts from all institutions attended
Program name: Prevention Science and Community Health MS
Prevention Science and Community Health PhD

Requirements: A bachelor’s degree in art, design, or a related field. The official Graduate Record Examination (GRE) is NOT REQUIRED for admission to this program. Two (2) letters of reference. A letter of intent that states the student’s career goals. A professional résumé. A link to an online portfolio with 15-20 images of creative work. The portfolio should demonstrate the applicant’s skills and interests.
Program name: Product Design MS: Cosmetics and Consumer Goods

Requirements:
Completed application to the Office of Graduate Admissions
Official transcripts from all institutions attended
A minimum undergraduate GPA of 2.75 on a 4.0 scale
Undergraduate coursework in biology and chemistry, including organic chemistry and biochemistry
Three letters of recommendation
A resume
A personal statement describing research experience, career goals and interest in the program
Program name: Product Design MS: Pharmaceutical and Biopharmaceutical

Requirements: Admission to Graduate Studies. Minimum 2.75 GPA on a 4.0 scale on all undergraduate work. Master's Degree in a Social Science field (Education, Counseling, Psychology, Sociology) is preferred but not required.

Unconditional admission to the University of North Alabama Graduate Studies. Clear and unencumbered Registered Nurse license in the state where clinicals will be completed. Master of Science degree in Nursing from an accredited (ACEN or CCNE) university with a minimum 3.0 GPA. National certification as an advanced practice nurse. Completion of the following graduate courses with a "B" or better: Advanced Pathophysiology, Advanced Pharmacology, and Advanced Physical Assessment. PMHNP applicants must have one year of full-time work experience as a Registered Nurse in a psychiatric mental health setting within the last five years. Submit a resume. Submit a copy of APRN national certification. Submit a copy of graduate transcripts. Submit to a formal interview with graduate nursing faculty.
Program name: Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner Cert

Requirements:
To be admitted to the MPA Program, a student must meet the admission requirements of the Office of Graduate Studies. In addition, the student must meet the requirements of the MPA program, which are as follows:

1. Submit an application for admission to graduate study.
2. Submit official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended.
3. Possess an overall undergraduate grade point average of 2.75 or higher on a 4.0 scale.
4. Submit a letter of application to the MPA Program Director. The letter of application will be used to determine the applicant’s aptitude for graduate study and for a public service career. The letter must address the following areas:
   * Why the applicant wants to pursue the MPA degree.
   * The applicant’s career goals.
   * What the applicant expects to gain from the MPA program.
   * The applicant's understanding of public service.
5. Submit a writing sample that demonstrates the applicant’s ability to write clearly and concisely. The writing sample may be a paper written for a previous course or a work product.
6. Submit two letters of recommendation.

Unconditional Admission: An undergraduate degree from a regionally accredited institution with a cumulative GPA of 2.75 or higher on a 4.0 scale. Submit an application for admission, official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended, and the non-refundable application fee. Submit a statement of purpose for seeking the MPA degree at UNA (250-500 words). Submit a current resume or vita. Submit an academic or professional writing sample. Submit three letters of recommendation from professional or academic sources.

Baccalaureate degree from an accredited institution.
Minimum 2.5 GPA on a 4.0 scale on all previous coursework.
Official transcripts from all institutions attended.
UNA Graduate application for admission.
Application fee.

An application to The University of Alabama Graduate School; Official transcripts from all institutions attended; A bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited institution; A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale; A three- to five-page statement of purpose detailing your interest in public health, career goals and how the MPH degree will help you achieve them; Three letters of recommendation; A current résumé or curriculum vitae; GRE is not required for admission.

Admission to the Master of Health Administration Program is open to qualified holders of bachelor’s degrees from regionally accredited institutions. Applicants are admitted to the program on the basis of criteria that suggest a high probability of success. The following are the requirements for admission:

1. Completed Application for Graduate Studies.
2. Official transcript(s) from all colleges/universities attended with a posted bachelor's degree from a regionally accredited institution submitted directly from the colleges or universities.
3. Bachelor's degree with a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.75 on a 4.0 scale.
4. Submission of a current resume.
5. Submission of a letter of intent.
6. Submission of two letters of recommendation.

Students applying for admission must submit the following to the Office of Graduate Admissions:
1. Completed UNA Graduate Application and fee.
2. Official transcripts from all postsecondary institutions attended submitted directly to the Office of Graduate Admissions from the institution. The transcript must document a conferred bachelor's degree from a regionally accredited institution.
3. An undergraduate GPA of 2.75 on a 4.0 scale.
4. Personal statement of no more than 500 words describing the applicant's purpose in pursuing graduate study in public health.
5. Resume
6. GRE Scores (waived through Fall 2024). Applicants may provide to strengthen their application.
7. Three recommendation forms.
8. A student who has a cumulative undergraduate GPA between 2.5 and 2.74 may be admitted on a conditional basis.

Overall GPA of 3.0 or higher. Grade of 'B' or better in all pre-requisite courses for the Public Health Program. Submit a formal application to the Graduate Admissions office. Submit a one-page, double-spaced personal statement addressing why you want to be a public health professional and what makes you a good candidate for the Public Health program and a career in public health. Submit three letters of recommendation with at least one letter from a UNA faculty member. Submit a resume or curriculum vitae. Once a complete application has been submitted, the applicant will be scheduled for an interview with the Graduate Coordinator.

Admission to the Master of Public Policy (MPP) program is granted through the UNA Office of Graduate Admissions.

Applicants for the Master of Public Policy must meet the following requirements:

* An official transcript from the college or university that awarded the baccalaureate degree, with a minimum cumulative undergraduate GPA of 2.75 on a 4.0 scale.
* Two letters of recommendation from former professors or professionals familiar with the applicant’s academic and/or professional capabilities.
* A current résumé.
* A 500-word statement of purpose outlining the applicant’s reasons for pursuing the MPP degree.
* For applicants with a GPA below 2.75, a 300-word statement explaining any extenuating circumstances for the lower GPA.
* The Graduate Record Examination (GRE) is not required for admission into the MPP program.
* The Public Affairs program coordinator may request a meeting (phone, online, or in-person) with the applicant if the need for one is determined.

The application process for the Valenti School of Communication's graduate program is a two-step process. In addition to applying to the University of Houston graduate school, applicants must submit the following supplemental materials: A 500-word statement of purpose detailing your interest in the graduate program, your career goals and how the M.A. program will help you achieve them; A current resume; A writing sample (e.g., a paper you have written for a class, a press release, or a research paper); Three letters of recommendation from faculty or professionals; Official transcripts from all previous institutions; Official GRE scores (UH code 6870). GRE waivers are available.

In addition to meeting the general requirements for admission to the Office of Graduate Studies, the applicant must meet the following program requirements: 1. A bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited institution. 2. At least a 2.75 overall GPA on all undergraduate work. 3. Two letters of recommendation. 4. A personal essay that introduces the student and explains the student’s reasons for pursuing the master’s degree in writing. 5. A portfolio of student writing (approximately 15-20 pages).
